newsitem.title: CANADA: Thiessen said expected dlr rise keeping rates low.
newsitem.headline: Thiessen said expected dlr rise keeping rates low.

text.p: Bank of Canada Governor Gordon Thiessen on Friday said an expectation that the Canadian dollar will gradually rise over time is the reason Canadian interest rates are now mostly lower than U.S. rates.

"If Canadian interest rates are going to go below American rates, as they are from one day out to 20 years, what you do have to have is an expectation of a rising currency. That is the only way that you end up over time having lower interest rates in Canada than the United States," said Thiessen.
Thiessen made the statement in response to a question about whether the negative spreads that currently exist between Canadian and U.S. interest rates along most of the yield curve were sustainable.

"People only accept lower interest rates in one country than another if they expect to compensated, because they expect to be compensated by a rise in the currency. It is only with the expectation of a gradually rising currency that you end up have lower interest rates in Canada than the U.S. Whether that low differential now is sustainable, I don't know," said Thiessen.
